While Brill sniffs at single payer, the example he most often uses is Medicare. One hospital he cites is Stamford, where i've had excellent care and total confusion for years about billing, both before i began medicare 10 years ago and since.

My ecperience demonstrates the efficiency of Medicare despite all the weight against it from the hospital lobby.

While on full private insurance, we repeatedly had billing issues. At a time I was quite ill I was being dunned for rather small amount for deductible compared to overall charges. I ranted at the hospital about the dunning threats while my wife and i st dow both to write a check and understand what had happened. We discovered we had paid the bill. Indeed, we had paid the same bill three seperate times over a span of several months. We extractedvan apology, but we were plagued for years with overbilling.

Something brought that to an abrupt halt. Medicare. Fifteen years of billing problems disappeared as soon as i became covered by Medicare.

I've been hospitalized a number of times. One for a complicated bit of cervical surgery was amazing. We and the neurosurgeon knew the Medicare payment to him. Medicare sent us copies of hospital charges and Medicare payments. Two nights, a surgical suite, anesthesiologist, et, etc, came to about $100,000 (surgeon extra). medicare paid about 18 percent of he deadline figure.
Private insurance would not have paid much differently.Single payer works and costs less.

In Econ 101, they compare insurance companies to casinos rather than banks. We bet that we'll suffer some misfortune, and the insurance company bets that we won't suffer that misfortune. If everyone puts money in the pot, and the insurance company has calculated the probabilities correctly, there'll be enough to pay the claims made.

This explains the "pre-existing condition" scenario - if everyone KNOWS whether or not they're going to suffer the misfortune, the only people who will buy insurance are the ones that know they'll need to be reimbursed for that type of loss. There wouldn't be enough money in the fund to pay out all those claims, and the insurer would go broke.

This is why the national health insurance plans require everyone to pay into the fund.

(On a side note - one of the reasons health care is so expensive in the US is that hospitals must treat anyone that arrives at the emergency room, regardless of whether they can pay. The cost of the unrecoverable debt is spread out to other patients that don't have insurance but CAN pay (the negotiated rates paid by insurance companies don't have this extra burden.) If we have a system where everyone is covered, the hospitals will get paid for everyone that they treat - and the bills won't need to cover bad debt allowances..

Lasik and cosmetic procedures are elective and have nothing to do with a health need.  Since there is no third party payer and no medical need there is price competition.

Urgent care clinics, cash-only private practices, and Walmart's aforementioned $4 prescriptions are all examples of *non-elective* medical care operating outside the third-payer complex. Elective treatments are a valid comparison because there is indeed a market mechanism containing costs--it disproves the story about how modern medical technology or Baumol's' cost disease is intrinsically driving up costs.

Non-elective doesn't mean no choice of treatment and markets are possible. Today, a miracle drug that cures heart disease would fail because it's much more profitable to create treatments that bilk insurance for long periods without actually curing conditions.

If there were a market for medical *services* as opposed to *insurance*, there might be incentives to create cheaper medical services. We see evidence of cost reductions due to technological advance in the few places where a cash market exists, such as Walmart's $4 generic prescriptions, LASIK surgery, etc.

Since the legal systems of most countries have mostly outlawed medical services choices, then a single payer system that can ration service and contain costs is the next best thing.

If a country provides a clear pathway out of poverty, such as education, and if the poverty isn't so deep that kids can't concentrate at school because they're hungry, maybe.

They have to be far more talented to get the same grades. And when they do finish school, they're being asked to take on massive debt for basic post-school studies. They don't have parents who can contribute and they don't have social capital to draw on.

Not convinced? Well how about the fact that social mobility in the US is more stagnant than it is in Europe. There is a LOT wrong with a society not caring about developing a big underclass.

All of this discussion or any discussion on prosperity seems to pre-suppose two things; first, that everyone can or should be prosperous and, second that there is some fundamental problem with having poor people in our society.

The reason this matters is that it seems in the US we are constantly trying to rig our system to accommodate the idea that everyone deserves a flat-screen TV, new car and a house. This idea is in-line with Ms. Prasad's thinking on our consumer focus in the US. American prosperity seems to come, not from thrift and sacrifice, but from access to capital....for everyone.

But the second issue that neither Ms. Prasad nor Europeans seem to accept is that there is something wrong with having poor people in your society. What should concern Americans and anyone that values a stable society, is if the poor REMAIN poor. For example, if you just arrived in the US with no education and skills, you'll likely be poor. But if our system provides access to education and is fair about employment, we'd hope to find that you or your children are not poor 30-40 years on. That is the definition of upward mobility. So as long as the poor people are changing every few years and becoming prosperous, who cares if we get new poor people arriving and wanting to move up? That would just make us a land of opportunity rather than a land of gifts.

Dear Mr. Wenz,

Canadian bitumen is indeed diluted with lighter hydrocarbons to reduce its viscosity for pumping. That diluent comes from two sources; synthetic crude oil, which, when combined with bitumen, makes "synbit", or light Canadian natural gas liquids condensate, which when mixed with bitumen makes "dilbit".

That condensate may contain a range of hydrocarbons from propane to butane through pentane, hexane, septane and octane.

Not benzene. Look it up. Benzene is traditionally producedby distillation of coal tar. Are you confusing it with "Benzine", European for C5-C8 hydrocarbon mixtures which we Americans call "gasoline"?

The pipelines will also handle conventional crudes, batched between "pigs".These conventional crudes will have a very wide array of hydrocarbons; there might indeed be some benzene in there somewhere.

Because conventional crude oils contain over 600 hydrocarbon compounds of all sorts. There are several of them nasty enough that I wouldn't want them in my soup.

The State Department has it right in this instance. A pipeline which (occasionally, among other things) handles dilbit is no more (and admittedly no less) of a risk to the public than a conventional crude oil line.

And the pressure? Pipelines are built of steel strong enough and thick enough to handle the maximum allowable working pressure (MAWP); pipeline operators are not allowed to exceed MAWP.

The fear generated over the Keystone Pipeline is counterfactual hyperbole.
